predictions: Zully Broussard donated one of her kidneys to a stranger, sparking a chain reaction that led to six patients receiving transplants. Data processing of genetic profiles, made possible by a computer program, matched the donors and recipients, making the chain possible.

The article marks the 20th anniversary of Major League Soccer (MLS) with a significant increase in popularity, attendance, and revenue. The league has doubled in size and value, with a new TV deal worth $700 million. However, challenges remain in attracting and retaining top talent.

French striker Bafetimbi Gomis collapsed during Swansea's 3-2 loss at Tottenham, but is now "feeling well" after treatment. He had similar fainting spells in France and was signed by Swansea despite low blood pressure issues. Gomis spent the night in hospital as a precaution.

Rory McIlroy showed frustration on the 8th hole of the WGC Cadillac Championship, hitting his 3-iron into a lake and then launching it into the water. He finished the round with a 70, one-under par, and is eight shots behind leader JB Holmes.

A 13-year-old Pennsylvania eighth-grader, Cayman Naib, has been missing since Wednesday. Hundreds of volunteers are searching for him, and his parents believe he may have left school due to an email about overdue homework. His phone was out of power at the time.

Former MLB pitcher Curt Schilling fired back at Twitter trolls who made vulgar comments about his 17-year-old daughter, Gabby. He tracked down the abusers and had them suspended or fired, and is considering taking legal action. Schilling's actions are a powerful example of accountability and protective parenting.

Two American women, aged 21 and 25, were arrested for carving their initials into a wall at Rome's Colosseum. They may face a fine for "aggravated damage" and are not the first tourists to be caught vandalizing the historic landmark.

Prince and 3rdEyeGirl are bringing the Hit & Run Tour to the US for the first time, with a scheduled show in Louisville, Kentucky on March 14. Tickets go on sale March 9 at 10 a.m. local time, with portions donated to local charities.

A shooting at a bar in Bamako, Mali, killed 5 people, including French and Belgian citizens, and wounded 8 others. Authorities attributed the attack to a "criminal and terrorist act" by al-Murabitun, a North African jihadist group. The US and France condemned the attack.

Manchester United's Jonny Evans and Newcastle's Papiss Cisse have been charged by the Football Association for allegedly spitting during an altercation in a Premier League game. They have until Friday to respond, and could face 6-game bans if found guilty. Both players released statements denying the allegations.

The article is from a CNN Student News program from March 10, 2015. The program covers various international topics, including a plane attempting to circumnavigate the globe powered by the sun, mysterious craters in northern Asia, and a view of Mount Everest.

Nine foreign workers, including four Filipinos, an Austrian, a Czech, and a Ghanaian, are believed to be held by ISIS-affiliated militants in Libya after an attack on an oil field. The Philippine foreign ministry is coordinating with Austrian and Libyan authorities to secure their release.

Wichita high school Principal Sherman Padgett was initially hesitant to participate in a senior prank, but changed his mind when students began dropping notes of praise and thanks into a bucket, expressing gratitude for his support and guidance throughout their high school years.

Comic book artist Norman Lee, 47, went missing while snorkeling in the Cayman Islands. A recovery mission is underway, but it's unlikely to find him. Lee was known for his work on DC and Marvel comics and has received tributes from friends, fans, and colleagues.

The article discusses the anniversary of several historic events, including a civil rights march, a Malaysia Airlines flight disappearance, and International Women's Day. It also mentions that CNN Student News will cover these events on Monday. The article provides a link to the show's transcript and invites students to request a mention on the "Roll Call" by commenting on the page with their school information.

Jessie Usher has been cast in the sequel "Independence Day 2" alongside Liam Hemsworth and Jeff Goldblum. Usher will play the son of Will Smith's character, marking a significant film role for the "Survivor's Remorse" star. The film is set for release on June 24, 2016.

Former Vice President Walter Mondale, 87, was released from the Mayo Clinic after being admitted with influenza. He was treated for flu and cold symptoms and is doing well, according to his friend Jimmy Carter. Mondale had a routine checkup after experiencing a fever.

Entrepreneur Kyle Waring is selling Boston-area snow online, shipping 6 pounds of snow for $89. His website, ShipSnowYo.com, has received over 133 orders, with 30 on Tuesday alone. Waring aims to capitalize on the region's record-breaking snowfall, calling it "our nightmare is your dream!"

A group of Syrian and Iraqi refugee women in Jordan, like Farah, Fatiya, and Zainab, are finding ways to rebuild their lives despite limited options. They're building vocational skills, financial literacy, and social networks, challenging cultural norms and exposing themselves to abuse.

Real Madrid lost 1-0 to Athletic Bilbao, potentially handing Barcelona the La Liga lead. Real's lack of cutting edge was a concern, with only one goal in two games. Bilbao's Aritz Aduriz scored the winner, while Gareth Bale hit the post in the second half.

A 40-year-old man in Japan's Sumoto city has been arrested for fatally stabbing five neighbors, including three women and two men, in a farming community. The victims lived within 100 meters of the suspect's home and shared the same surname, but it's unclear if they're related.

A suicide attacker detonated a car bomb near a police vehicle in Helmand province, Afghanistan, killing 7 people and injuring 23 others, including several children. The attack occurred in the Bolan area of Lashkar Gah city, with most casualties being civilians, but the attacker's identity is unknown.

Pakistan's highest court ordered the release of Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, alleged mastermind of the 2008 Mumbai attacks, citing his detention as illegal. The decision was met with outrage from India, which summoned the Pakistani high commissioner to express its strong feelings. Lakhvi was granted bail last year.

A DeKalb County, Georgia police officer shot and killed an unarmed African-American man who was naked and running in a metro Atlanta apartment complex. The officer fired two shots, and the case is being investigated by the Georgia Bureau of Investigations.

A photo of a weasel clinging to the back of a flying woodpecker near London has gone viral. The weasel, known as a "least weasel," was seen struggling to hold on as the bird flew away. Experts say it's possible the weasel mistook the bird for food.

Kanye West fans are selling plastic bags of air allegedly captured at his concerts on eBay, with prices ranging from $4,999 to $60,000. The "bagged air" gag has inspired similar items, while authentic Yeezy 750 Boost sneakers are also being sold on the site for $1,700-$5,000.

A Delta Air Lines plane skidded off the runway at LaGuardia Airport due to brake issues during landing. The crew cited a lack of deceleration from the wheel brake, despite auto brakes being set to "max." 23 passengers were injured, and the cause remains under investigation.

Over 100 schools in Pakistan have been renamed in honor of students killed in a Taliban siege at the Army Public School in Peshawar last year. The gesture remembers the bravery of students who lost their lives during the December 16 attack, resulting in 145 deaths.

The Salvation Army in South Africa used the viral "dress" ad to raise awareness about domestic violence, featuring a model wearing a black and blue dress with bruises. The ad received a positive response, highlighting how people's perceptions of color can be influenced by genetics.

NASCAR lifted driver Kurt Busch's suspension, making him eligible to return immediately under indefinite probation. He had been suspended after a civil court found probable domestic violence against his ex-girlfriend. Busch completed a reinstatement program and addressed his behavior, but must undergo additional steps.

The interim report on MH370's disappearance reveals a chaotic response from air traffic controllers, with a 5-hour delay in issuing a distress signal and a 5-hour delay in launching search flights. Radar data was not immediately utilized, leading to a lost week in the search effort.

A ferry capsized in Myanmar's Sittwe city, killing 21 people and leaving 21 missing. At least 167 people were rescued. The incident occurred in bad weather, similar to a recent ferry disaster in Bangladesh that killed 68 people. Fatal ferry accidents are common in the region.

Myanmar warplanes dropped a bomb on a Chinese sugarcane field, killing 4 civilians and injuring 9. China responded by sending fighter jets to patrol the border and summoned Myanmar's ambassador. Beijing called for an investigation and punishment for those responsible, amid ongoing border clashes.

The article warns about the dangers of self-diagnosing online, citing five common mistakes: searching blindly, flailing in forums, getting emotional, keeping mum around doctors, and putting off the inevitable. Experts advise using reputable sources, being cautious of misinformation, and seeking professional help when needed.

A 19-year-old man, Erich Nowsch Jr., has been indicted for fatally shooting his neighbor, Tammy Meyers, 44, in front of her home in Nevada. Nowsch's attorney claims self-defense, but police say he shot Meyers after a confrontation. Nowsch faces murder, attempted murder, and firing a gun charges.

The article suggests that despite strained race relations, there is an opportunity to address issues through positive action. It proposes increasing community policing, engaging citizens in decision-making, and fostering mutual respect between law enforcement and minority communities. This can lead to a shift from "HandsUpDon'tShoot" to "HandsTogetherInTrust."

A North Korean diplomat, Son Young Nam, was caught carrying 27kg of undeclared gold at Dhaka's airport. He initially refused to let his bag be searched, claiming it was an electric motor. The incident has sparked a protest from Bangladesh's government, with its implications unclear.

Rescuers found 2-year-old Lily hanging upside down in her car after it crashed into a Utah river, killing her mother, Lynn Groesbeck. Lily is awake and recovering, singing nursery rhymes and waving at her father, Deven Trafny, who feels "blessed" to have his daughter alive.

A medical helicopter carrying at least three people, including employees from EagleMed LLC, crashed in Eufaula, Oklahoma, near Lake Eufaula. The FAA is investigating, and local authorities are handling the scene. This incident comes after a separate Army Black Hawk helicopter crash in Florida, killing 11 service members.

Monohm's Runcible is a circular, palm-sized device that challenges the rectangular status quo of smartphones. The startup aims to create a more self-contained, complete experience, free from notifications and distractions. Its circular frame invites developers to explore new metaphors and interactions.

The official Star Wars universe is introducing its first gay character, Moff Mors, a capable but flawed Imperial official, in the upcoming novel "Lords of the Sith". Moff Mors is a lesbian, marking a significant milestone in the franchise's representation of LGBTQ+ individuals.

A suicide bombing attack in Lahore, Pakistan, killed at least 14 people and wounded dozens more, targeting a Christian community. The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility, warning of more attacks. The attack is the latest in a series of attacks on Pakistan's Christian community and minority groups.

The IRS impersonation scam is a massive scam, with over $15 million lost since 2013, targeting over 3,000 victims. Scammers use stolen identities, phishing, and Google Earth to convince victims to send money. Authorities believe the scammers are operating out of India, and victims are often immigrants or the elderly.

The article discusses the attempts by some Republicans to undermine President Obama's Iranian policy, comparing it to past instances of bipartisan foreign policy meddling. Examples include Sen. Edward Kennedy's secret diplomacy with the Soviet Union and President Nixon's efforts to undermine the peace talks in Vietnam.

Pope Francis, 78, expects his papacy to be brief, possibly 4-5 years. He feels God only wanted him to lead the Roman Catholic Church for a short time. He also misses going out in public without being recognized and enjoys calling on Pope Emeritus Benedict.

Actor Ashton Kutcher sparked a conversation about the lack of diaper changing tables in public men's rooms after posting about his experience as a new father. Many praised him for raising the issue, with some suggesting businesses like Walmart and Cracker Barrel often have changing tables.

Spain's Caminito del Rey, a 7.7km cliffside trail, will reopen on March 26 after a 12-year closure due to fatal accidents. The trail, which features a 100m-high boardwalk, was rebuilt with a €5.8 million budget. Entry will be free for 6 months, with limited visiting hours.

Israeli presidential candidate Isaac Herzog is leading in polls ahead of the March 17 election. He promises to work with the US and Europe to ensure Israel's safety, restart stalled peace talks with the Palestinians, and address social inequality. He believes it's his destiny to be prime minister.

Hundreds of thousands of Brazilians protested against President Dilma Rousseff, calling for her impeachment due to economic woes and a massive Petrobras scandal. Rousseff, a former Petrobras chairwoman, denies personal involvement but faces public pressure. Protests are expected to continue, potentially affecting her presidency.

Turkish officials detained 16 Indonesian citizens, including 11 minors, who confessed to planning to cross into Syria. The group was stopped in Gaziantep, Turkey, and the Indonesian government is sending a security team to investigate their objectives and plans, separate from another group of 16 Indonesians.

A Tamil news station in southern India, Puthiya Thalaimurai, was attacked with crude bombs after airing a show about a traditional necklace worn by married women, deemed offensive by hardline Hindu groups. The attack highlights India's struggles with free speech and censorship.

Serena Williams returns to the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells 14 years after a tumultuous 2001 tournament, where she faced racism and her father's alleged interference. The event has apologized and welcomed her back, with her mother and some family members attending.

A mobile phone app has led to a 35% increase in reported incidents of abusive behavior by football fans, with 184 incidents recorded in the last 5 months of 2014. The app, launched by anti-racism organization Kick It Out, encourages anonymous reporting and triggers investigations by the English Football Association.

The article highlights the importance of parents being aware of the law and their children's legal rights, particularly for teens. Author Lisa Green, a journalist, lawyer, and TV analyst, emphasizes that parents should have a criminal defense lawyer in mind, just in case. She advises parents to educate themselves on the law, track down a good lawyer, and be prepared to defend their child if needed. Green stresses that parents should not absolve their children of responsibility, but rather be aware of their rights and help them use better judgment.

Spanish photographer Ignacio Evangelista captured abandoned Schengen checkpoints across Europe, documenting the unusual architecture and human history of these former border control points. His project, "After Schengen," showcases the transformation of Europe's frontiers since the agreement lifted frontier controls in 2005.

Red Bull driver Daniel Ricciardo is set to compete in the Australian Grand Prix, his home race. He experienced frustration last year when he was disqualified due to exceeding the maximum fuel flow rate. Ricciardo is looking to redeem himself and make the most of the hype surrounding the event.

"Cinderella" opened with an estimated $70.1 million, beating expectations and topping last year's "Maleficent" opening. The live-action retelling, directed by Kenneth Branagh, has a 83% Rotten Tomatoes rating. Liam Neeson's "Run All Night" debuted weakly, while "It Follows" had the best per-theater average in limited release.

Harper Lee, 88, is moving forward with publishing her book "Go Set a Watchman" despite concerns about her ability to consent. An Alabama Securities Commission investigation found Lee understood the process and wanted her book published. The investigation is now closed.

A Navy sailor's photo with his baby cradled in the American flag sparked debate over whether it was patriotic or desecrating the flag. The photographer, a Navy wife, defended the image, saying it showed what it means to be an American.

Professor Candida Moss, a New Testament expert, answers questions from CNN's "Finding Jesus" series. 

- Moss explains that the number 40 in the Bible often represents a full or complete period of time, like a narrative stock number.
- There was likely tension between Jesus' followers and John the Baptist's followers, as they had separate ministries and were competitors in the ancient religious marketplace.
- DNA tests on the Shroud of Turin bones suggest a probable Semitic origin, but cannot determine if the person was Jewish or from the tribe of Levi.
- There are external historical references to John the Baptist, including a

Professor Andre Spicer warns that Apple's new smartwatch may have a "hidden, darker side." While it can help with time management, it can also lead to a "phantom device effect" where users compulsively check their watch for information, extending work into personal life and fueling an unhealthy obsession with personal wellness.

Police raided Robert Durst's Houston home on Tuesday, a day after he was charged with first-degree murder in connection with the 2000 killing of his friend Susan Berman. Durst remains jailed in New Orleans, facing additional charges, and his attorney claims the raid is a "ruse" to embarrass him.

The Southern Poverty Law Center's annual report shows a 17% decline in hate groups in the US, with the number of Ku Klux Klan chapters dropping by 50%. The decline may be due to economic factors, law enforcement, and increased social costs of being associated with hate groups.

Rev. Fred Craddock, a renowned preacher known for his unique and engaging style, has died at 86. He redefined the art of preaching with his conversational style, incorporating storytelling, foreshadowing, and surprise endings. A devoted servant of the church and Jesus Christ, he left a lasting impact.

The State Department has started automatically preserving high-level officials' emails, a change that began in February. This revelation comes amid controversy over former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's email use. Clinton claimed she thought her communications to senior officials were always saved.

Two American aid workers with high-risk exposure to Ebola in Sierra Leone returned to the US for monitoring. Eight colleagues have already been flown back, with one in critical condition at the NIH. All are being closely watched for signs of the disease.

Danny Welbeck scored the winner for Arsenal in a 2-1 FA Cup victory over Manchester United at Old Trafford. Welbeck capitalized on a mistake by Antonio Valencia to score just after the hour mark, securing a semifinal spot for Arsenal. Angel Di Maria was also sent off for United.

Loistine Hoskin's 1996 Oldsmobile was towed in 2009 after a Ferguson, Missouri, ticket for a missing tire. She paid $1,200 in fines, but the car is now lost. The US Justice Department found a "pattern and practice" of racial discrimination in Ferguson's government, targeting African-Americans for tickets and fines.

Russian President Vladimir Putin appeared in photos released by the Kremlin after a week of speculation over his health. His spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, downplayed concerns, joking that the rumors were due to "spring fever." Putin's last public appearance was on International Women's Day.

Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) advanced to the Champions League quarterfinals after a 2-1 aggregate win over Chelsea. Thiago Silva's handball initially gave Chelsea a 2-1 lead, but Silva scored a late equalizer and PSG won 3-2 in extra time. PSG played with 10 men for most of the game.

The UK's Metropolitan Police has summoned 5 Chelsea football fans for alleged racism after a video showed them preventing a black man from boarding the Paris Metro and chanting racist slogans. The fans face a life ban if found guilty and could face up to 6 months in prison.

Sotheby's is auctioning a 900,000-dollar sculpture by Maurizio Cattelan, documenting England's defeats from 1874 to 1998. The black granite piece, titled "Football," chronicles 27 losses, including the 1998 World Cup. The work is part of Cattelan's satirical art, exploring themes of pride, missed opportunities, and death.

Tens of thousands gathered in Tel Aviv's Yitzhak Rabin Square, calling for a change in Israeli leadership amid growing discontent with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's administration. The rally, "Israel Wants Change," aims to reduce the cost of living and promote a two-state solution, without promoting a specific candidate.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame announced its 30th Annual Induction Ceremony, featuring A-list presenters and performers. The ceremony will honor 7 artists, including Paul McCartney, Patti Smith, and John Legend, with performances by Beck, Jimmie Vaughan, and others. It airs on HBO on May 30.

Tairod Nathan Webster Pugh, a 47-year-old former US Air Force veteran, pleaded not guilty to terror-related charges for allegedly trying to join ISIS in Syria. He was arrested in January after being denied entry to Turkey and found with jihadist propaganda materials on his devices.

The article argues that Silicon Valley is erasing jobs, leaving millennials financially stranded. Despite falling unemployment, 44% of young people are stuck in low-paying jobs, and only 36% of college grads earn at least $45,000. The digital economy is creating a "winner-take-all" scenario with minimal job security.

The wreck of the CSS Georgia, a Confederate ironclad, has been recovered from the Savannah River. Divers have brought up over 400 artifacts, including leg irons, cannons, and musket parts. Conservation efforts are underway to preserve the artifacts for eventual display, with a focus on the human side of the ship's crew.

In New Zealand, vigilante motorists have taken to snatching car keys from foreign drivers amid concerns over reckless driving by tourists. Authorities condemn the actions, but acknowledge the issue, with 8 people killed in crashes involving foreign drivers in a fortnight.

Tropical Cyclone Pam devastated the capital of Vanuatu, Port Vila, with "unbelievable destruction" reported by relief workers. The storm, a Category 4 hurricane, dumped over 9 inches of rain and had wind gusts of up to 190 mph, causing widespread damage and loss of homes.

In Esfahan, Iran, the Jewish community openly practices their faith, with a synagogue on Palestine Square and public prayers several times a day. Despite Iran's hostility towards Israel, community members feel at home and prioritize unity and peace, with no reported issues with Shia neighbors.

The upcoming Israeli elections are seen as crucial, but the results are unlikely to change the country's policy on the Palestinian territories. Both Netanyahu and Herzog have negligible differences in their stance on the occupation, with neither having a real intention to end it.

A video allegedly shows three British schoolgirls, Shamima Begum, Kadiza Sultana, and Amira Abase, preparing to cross the Turkish border into Syria, where they are believed to have joined ISIS. The video, released by Turkish TV network A Haber, shows the girls with luggage and a man helping them.

Kerry Washington is set to star as Anita Hill in HBO's upcoming TV movie "Confirmation," which details the 1991 Clarence Thomas-Hill Supreme Court nomination hearings. Academy Award-nominated writer Susannah Grant is also executive producing the drama, alongside Washington and Groundswell Productions.

47 Republican Senators sent a letter to Iran aimed at undermining President Obama's diplomatic efforts, violating the Logan Act. This is part of a pattern of disrespect towards Obama, including criticism from politicians and media outlets, and implicit racial bias.

The author interviewed Prince Charles and his wife Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, at their Scottish home, Birkhall. Despite initial rejections, they granted a rare interview, showcasing Prince Charles' comfort and authenticity on camera. The author also captured intimate moments of the couple's private life.

A University of Virginia student, Martese Johnson, was arrested and severely injured after being pinned to the ground by police. A campus forum is scheduled to discuss allegations of brutality and police brutality, with representatives from police and the university attending.

The article tells the story of Kelly Gissendaner, a woman on death row who has undergone a significant transformation through her participation in a theology program. Despite being sentenced to death and living in solitary confinement, Kelly has found joy, gratitude, and a sense of purpose through her studies and relationships with her instructors. Her journey has been marked by moments of profound remorse, forgiveness, and hope, and has inspired those around her to reexamine the truths of Christian faith.

Boston police officers testified about the chaotic shootout with the Boston Marathon bombing suspects, Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, on April 19, 2013. The brothers fired guns, threw bombs, and tried to run officers over with a stolen SUV. Tamerlan died from injuries, and Dzhokhar was later caught.

An Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed in the Florida Panhandle, killing all 11 on board, including 7 Marines and 4 Louisiana National Guard members. The operation has transitioned to recovery, with the focus on recovering the helicopter and bodies. An investigation into the cause is underway.

Four Italian tourists were killed in a shooting at Tunisia's Bardo Museum. The bodies have returned to Italy, but 14 victims remain in the morgue. Tunisian authorities have identified two suspects, Yassine Labidi and Saber Khachnaou, and arrested nine people in connection with the attack.

Residents in Ferguson, Missouri, have filed an affidavit to try to oust Mayor James Knowles, citing his failure to rein in the police department during protests following the fatal shooting of Michael Brown. The mayor has indicated he won't step down.

Ozgecan Aslan, 20, was brutally murdered in Turkey after fighting off a sexual assault on a bus. Her death sparked widespread protests, with hundreds of thousands demanding better protection for women. Her father plans to use donations to establish a rehabilitation center for abusers.

Lindsey Vonn won a record-extending 65th World Cup super-G, taking the lead in the speed discipline. She's 8 points ahead of Tina Maze and 35 points ahead in downhill. Vonn aims to win two titles, but is 200 points behind Maze in the overall standings.

A 12-year-old girl in Texas was sold into sex trafficking by a family member. She endured abuse and eventually escaped. Thousands of children, including a 12-year-old in Minnesota, are still suffering from sex trafficking. Two bills aim to combat the issue, providing support for victims and prosecuting traffickers.

Following a deadly attack at Tunisia's Bardo Museum, a social media campaign "I will come to Tunisia" aims to protect the country's tourism industry, critical to its economy. Thousands express support and solidarity, with many travelers pledging to visit despite travel warnings.

Former Wimbledon champion Marion Bartoli is considering a return to tennis after announcing her retirement due to injury problems. Eight-time grand slam champion Jimmy Connors advises her to only return if fully committed. Bartoli won 8 WTA titles and reached quarterfinals of major tournaments.

Actress Liza Minnelli, 68, has entered a rehab facility for her addictions to alcohol and painkillers. She has struggled with substance abuse in the past, winning an Oscar in 1973 for her role in "Cabaret." Minnelli is making "excellent progress" at an undisclosed facility.

Zaur Dadayev, a primary suspect in Boris Nemtsov's shooting death, withdrew his confession, claiming he was under duress and tortured. Russia's Investigative Committee accused two human rights activists of interfering with the investigation, prompting Amnesty International to condemn the move as unfair.

The next police chief in Ferguson, Missouri, will need to address deep-seated distrust between the community and police. Cecil Smith, current police chief in Sanford, Florida, who navigated similar racial tensions after the Trayvon Martin shooting, advises a "lot of prayer and a little goading" to build trust.

The NCAA Tournament, or March Madness, is a highly anticipated event in college basketball. The 68-team tournament determines seedings and offers a chance for players to impress scouts from top pro teams. The tournament's egalitarian system pits powerhouse programs against smaller schools, creating a unique competition.

Google CFO Patrick Pichette's resignation memo sparked debate on work-life balance. Critics argue that his decision to quit his job to travel with his family sends the wrong message to those seeking balance, particularly women who are often expected to choose between work and family.

A.J. Pero, drummer for Twisted Sister, has died at 55 due to a massive heart attack. He was found on his tour bus in Poughkeepsie, New York, and passed away at the hospital. The band is "devastated" and will miss him on stage.

Mexican wrestling star Hijo del Perro Aguayo, 35, died after collapsing during a match in Tijuana. He was kicked by Rey Mysterio and left slumped against the ropes, but medical attention was delayed. The cause of death is unknown, and an investigation into possible manslaughter has been launched.

New Zealand police are investigating a threat to contaminate infant formula with 1080, a poison used for pest control, in an apparent attempt to blackmail the government. Police urge the public to help find the alleged blackmailer, who faces up to 14 years in jail.

Sigma Alpha Epsilon (SAE) is facing backlash after a video surfaced of fraternity members singing a racist chant. The university of Oklahoma severed ties with the fraternity, citing a history of hazing incidents, including 130 chapters cited or suspended since 2010, and at least 30 involving hazing.

Comic book characters Superman, Wonder Woman, and Archie Andrews have undergone significant changes. Superman now wears casual attire, including a t-shirt and jeans, and has shorter hair. Wonder Woman returns to wearing pants and a turtleneck, while Archie debuts a modern look for his upcoming TV show.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu won the election in a landslide, despite polls predicting a tight race. Experts attribute the surprise to biased polls, strategic voting, and Netanyahu's shift to the right, which cannibalized votes from other right-wing parties.

A new HBO documentary, "Montage of Heck," is set to premiere on May 4, offering an intimate portrayal of Nirvana frontman Kurt Cobain's life. The film features interviews with family members, including Courtney Love, and includes an unreleased 12-minute acoustic track by Cobain.

US Secretary of State John Kerry said progress has been made in nuclear talks with Iran, but "gaps" remain. The US and other P5+1 nations agree that Iran should not develop nuclear arms. Kerry emphasized the need for a "right deal" before the March 24 deadline.

Eleven US service members died in a helicopter crash off the Florida Panhandle. Seven were Marines, four served with the Louisiana National Guard, and one was a warrant officer. The victims included a Silver Star recipient and a Marine of the Year, who were remembered for their bravery and dedication.

The White House claims the Iran nuclear deal is a "nonbinding agreement" rather than a treaty, which requires Senate "advice and consent." Republicans disagree, saying it's a treaty that should be sent to Congress for approval. The distinction raises constitutional law questions.

Jeremy Clarkson, a Top Gear presenter, was suspended by the BBC pending an investigation after allegedly hitting a producer. The show's next episodes will not be aired, and a petition seeking his reinstatement has gathered over 300,000 signatures.

Dolce & Gabbana's fall collection in Milan celebrated "mamma" with feminine dresses and skirts adorned with roses, lace, and embroidered phrases like "I love you, mamma." The show featured models with their own children, creating a heartwarming tableau of moms and daughters.

Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Ya'alon denied allegations that a 19-year-old Israeli Arab man, Mohamed Said Ismail Musallam, was an Israeli spy. Musallam's family claims he was recruited by ISIS, not the Mossad, and was coerced into a false confession in a recent ISIS video.

Ferguson's police department is under scrutiny after a shooting of two officers, amid a broader issue of racial bias in US police departments. The town's militarized police presence and use of surplus military-grade weaponry exacerbate tensions, highlighting the need for drastic reforms and a new mindset on policing practices.

Two Chinese men, Han and Zhang, were jailed for selling military intelligence, including photos of China's first aircraft carrier, to foreign spies. Han took photos at a military base and Zhang sent over 500 images of the carrier to a foreign magazine.

CBS' "Supergirl" has released first-look photos of Melissa Benoist as the DC Comics character. The costume was designed by Colleen Atwood, and production on the pilot started in Los Angeles. The drama follows Kara Zor-El, Superman's cousin, as she navigates her powers and a foster family.

The article criticizes Republican senators for sending a letter to Iran's leaders, which was seen as an attempt to sabotage the nuclear deal, and Hillary Clinton's handling of her emails, which created a divisive issue. Both actions have deepened polarization and diminished the chances for bipartisan politics.

A University of Central Florida (UCF) team, Limbitless Solutions, created a 3D-printed robotic arm for 6-year-old Alex Pring, born with a missing arm. The arm, designed with a muscle sensor, allows Pring to open and close his hand. The project has inspired others, including a boy with a similar condition, Wyatt.

The author reflects on how their working mom and stay-at-home dad's roles in the 1980s mirrored the traditional "Leave It to Beaver" dynamic. However, their same-sex household has deconstructed these roles, with both partners contributing to household labor and childcare.

The Broadway debut of "Fish in the Dark" by Larry David sparked controversy over its portrayal of a Puerto Rican maid, Fabiana. Critics argued that the character's depiction was stereotypical and culturally insensitive. In contrast, a planned Asian adaptation of "Show Boat" was canceled due to concerns about cultural appropriation.

Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson reprised their roles as Derek Zoolander and Hansel McDonald in a surprise appearance at Valentino's Paris Fashion Week show. The duo, set to star in "Zoolander 2" (2016), brought back the iconic characters, sparking excitement among fans.

The University of Oklahoma is hiring a VP to oversee diversity programs amid a racist video controversy. The video, showing students chanting a racist slur, led to the expulsion of two students and the disbanding of the Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity.

Jeremy Clarkson, a BBC presenter, faces controversy after allegedly abusing his staff. Despite the backlash, his popularity grows, with fans defending him and his ratings increasing. Clarkson seems to thrive on controversy, using it to boost his profile and esteem among his followers.

University President David Boren responded swiftly and decisively to a video of fraternity members chanting a hateful, racist song. He expelled two students, severed ties with the fraternity, and called for a shift in social norms towards equal opportunity and mutual respect.

A Palestinian man in his early 20s from East Jerusalem rammed into a cyclist and 4 Israeli border police in Jerusalem, injuring them lightly to moderately. Authorities consider it a terror attack, and the suspect was shot and wounded before being taken into custody.

The National Gallery in London has banned selfie sticks, joining other museums worldwide. The ban aims to prevent invasion of personal space and potential damage to art. Creator of #MuseumSelfieDay, Mar Dixon, supports the ban, citing risks of knocking people or art while taking selfies inside museums.

The Republican Congress has manufactured a crisis by threatening to shut down the Department of Homeland Security, putting national security at risk. This is the latest example of their dysfunctional governing style, prioritizing special interests and extreme wing of the party over the middle class.

Australian pop star Cody Simpson is promoting the U.N.'s International Day of Happiness at SXSW. He curated the #HappySoundsLike playlist with other celebrities, featuring tracks like Bob Marley's "Three Little Birds." Simpson aims to spread happiness through music, saying it's an escape for people.

President Barack Obama attended the Gridiron Club dinner, sharing jokes about marijuana and Hillary Clinton's email controversy. He joked about being "yesterday's news" and Clinton having a server in her house. Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker also attended, addressing rumors about his presidential ambitions.

A 1,000-year-old mummified monk encased in a Buddha statue was stolen from a Chinese temple in 1995. The statue, identified as Liuquan, was discovered in the Netherlands and is now in a private collector's possession. An investigation is underway to repatriate the statue to China.

Pennsylvania State University's Kappa Delta Rho fraternity has been suspended after allegedly posting compromising photos of women on a private Facebook page. The university is investigating and considering whether to reinstate the fraternity or re-evaluate the fraternity system. The incident raises concerns about the university's handling of sex crimes.

The article from March 25, 2015, features news from around the world, including:

- The US maintaining troop levels in Afghanistan for the rest of the year
- Israel denying accusations of spying on US-Iran negotiations
- A passenger plane crash in the French Alps

Additionally, the article provides information on the CNN Student News program, including a transcript and a roll call for students to request to be featured on the show.

Parisa Tabriz, 31, is Google's "Security Princess," tasked with finding flaws in the company's web browser to protect users' data. She thinks like hackers to anticipate threats, and her role has evolved from 50 to over 500 security engineers in eight years, with a focus on combating government surveillance.

A previously unknown group, the Islamic State Hacking Division, posted the names, photos, and addresses of about 100 US troops online, calling for attacks. The US military is investigating, and officials are warning troops to limit personal info online. The threat is considered serious.

Serena Williams returned to the Indian Wells Tennis Garden, where she was booed in 2001, and received a standing ovation. The crowd's warm welcome, including tears from Williams, marked a significant moment for her. She feels she's already won, not just the tournament, but for equality and women's tennis.

Chuck Norris is celebrating his 75th birthday, but the calendar only turns 39. Born March 10, 1940, Norris is known for his martial arts skills and tough-guy persona. The joke about the calendar is a play on his supposed ability to defy time and beat anything.

Serena Williams returns to the Indian Wells tournament after a 13-year boycott due to fan hostility and perceived favoritism towards her sister Venus. She had her parents' support and forgiveness, and is now ready to face her first match, saying she's "looking forward to being strong."

Pi Day (3/14) is celebrated on March 14, but this year it extends to 3.1415. The tradition started at San Francisco's Exploratorium in 1988 and has grown to include math enthusiasts. Events include a Pi Procession, pie and pizza, and an Einstein lookalike contest.

The remains of Richard III, discovered in a Leicester parking lot in 2012, are to be reburied after years of research. DNA tests revealed he was fair-haired and blue-eyed, contradicting Shakespeare's depiction. Analysis of his diet and injuries also shed new light on his life and death.

Tom Hanks appears in a music video for Carly Rae Jepsen's "I Really Like You" as himself, lip-syncing to her song. He's a friend of Scooter Braun, Jepsen's manager, and even sang at Braun's wedding. Hanks' appearance was a suggestion from Jepsen, who thought it would be amusing.

A federal judge ordered the Defense Department to release photos of detainee abuse in Iraq and Afghanistan, but not immediately. The government has 60 days to appeal. The ACLU claims the photos are evidence of Bush administration policies and will help the public understand their implications.

Singer-songwriter David Crosby was involved in a car accident Sunday evening in Santa Ynez, California. He struck a jogger with his car at approximately 50 mph, causing multiple fractures. Crosby was cooperative and not impaired, and the jogger's injuries are not life-threatening.

Airstrikes began in Tikrit, Iraq, as part of a coalition effort to retake the city from ISIS. The strikes aim to destroy strongholds and enable Iraqi forces to maneuver and defeat ISIS. The goal is to pave the way for retaking Mosul, a larger city previously held by ISIS.

Denise Huskins, 29, was found safe in Huntington Beach, California, after being reported kidnapped in Vallejo, California. She had no apparent injuries and was reunited with her family. The case is being treated as a kidnapping for ransom, with police investigating and the FBI involved.

Retired NFL star Darren Sharper pleaded guilty to one count of sexual assault and one count of attempted sexual assault in Arizona. He was sentenced to 9 years in prison with no early release and lifetime probation. Sharper had faced 5 counts in Arizona and 2 in California.

A Germanwings plane crashed in the Alps, killing all 150 people on board. Initial clues include a rapid descent of 14,000 feet in 6 minutes, with the plane maintaining speed. No distress call was made, and the pilot's actions are being investigated.

The National Institutes of Health plans to admit an American healthcare worker with Ebola to its Maryland hospital after volunteering at an Ebola treatment center in Sierra Leone. This is the second person with Ebola to be admitted to the NIH hospital, following a nurse who recovered in 2014.

The VA is attempting to reallocate emergency funds meant for veterans' community care, despite thousands struggling to access promised care due to the VA's flawed implementation of the 40-mile rule. The author is introducing legislation to require the VA to utilize its authorities to offer community care.

Angelina Jolie, 39, underwent surgery to remove her ovaries and fallopian tubes due to her BRCA1 gene mutation, increasing her risk of breast and ovarian cancer. She had planned the surgery but was accelerated by a blood test, and further tests were negative for tumors.

The BBC suspended Jeremy Clarkson, host of "Top Gear," following a dispute with a producer. Clarkson apologized on Twitter, but fans expressed dismay, with over 147,000 signing a petition for his reinstatement. This is not the first controversy surrounding Clarkson, who has faced criticism for racist remarks and other incidents.

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church) denies allegations of not doing enough to prevent child abuse in its scouting troops. Elder L. Whitney Clayton says the church has a zero-tolerance policy and extensive training, but acknowledges the case of Melvin Novak, who was abused by a scoutmaster.

J.K. Rowling revealed in 2007 that Albus Dumbledore was gay in "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows." When a fan questioned it, Rowling responded, "Maybe because gay people just look like... people?" Her response was met with praise from fans, who appreciated her straightforward answer.

A reported kidnapping of a Vallejo, California woman for ransom was a hoax, police said. Denise Huskins, 29, was found safe in Huntington Beach, but her boyfriend and family are no longer cooperating. Authorities wasted resources on the case, which was deemed a "wild goose chase."

Rohana Rozhan, CEO of Astro Malaysia, was nicknamed "Rohana the Piranha" as a child due to her fierce independence. She now leads a $4.6 billion media company, producing 9,000 hours of original content annually, with a goal of empowering women to be the best in their roles.

Actor Jon Hamm, known for his role as Don Draper in "Mad Men," has completed a 30-day rehab stint for alcohol abuse. Hamm checked into Silver Hill Hospital in Connecticut with the support of his partner Jennifer Westfeldt. The news comes before the show's final episodes air on April 5.

Creflo Dollar, a prosperity preacher, is seeking $60 million to buy a Gulfstream G650 airplane for his church's ministry. He aims to raise $300 from 200,000 people to fund the $65 million jet, which will transport him and his family globally to spread the gospel.

A new study suggests Neanderthals were more cognitively advanced than previously thought. Researchers found modified eagle talons in Croatia, indicating Neanderthals created jewelry and possibly caught birds with advanced planning skills. This challenges the common caveman-like depiction of Neanderthals.

Two University of Oklahoma students, Parker Rice and Levi Pettit, were expelled for their roles in a racist fraternity video. Rice, a former high school football player, and Pettit, a former competitive golfer, apologized for their actions, calling them "wrong and reckless."

A British mother allowed her 11-year-old son to wear a "Fifty Shades of Grey" costume to school's World Book Day celebration, despite the school deeming it inappropriate. The mother defended the costume as light-hearted and tongue-in-cheek, while the school cited high standards for student behavior.

A Washington state trooper caught a driver using a cardboard cutout of Dos Equis' "The Most Interesting Man in the World" to try to use the HOV lane. The driver was laughing when stopped and received a $124 ticket. The trooper praised the driver's creativity.

Severe storms swept across Oklahoma, killing one person and injuring about two dozen others. A tornado ravaged a mobile home park, destroying dozens of trailers, and flattened a gymnastics studio. Gov. Mary Fallin declared a state of emergency for 25 counties, with significant damage reported across the state.

The article urges Republicans to reverse six years of failed Obama administration policies, focusing on undoing defense sequestration and defense cuts. A strong military is essential for national security, and current budget cuts will lead to a smaller, less capable military, posing a strategic weakness.

A massive winter storm is affecting 94 million people across the US, from New Mexico to southern New England. Over 2,000 miles of snowy misery is expected, with 6-10 inches of snow in some areas and widespread cancellations, including over 1,180 flights at Dallas/Fort Worth Airport.

Police in Detroit discovered the bodies of a 14-year-old girl and an 11-year-old boy inside a freezer and plastic bag. The mother, arrested on child abuse charges, is awaiting the medical examiner's report. Two older children living in the home are in protective custody.

Russian President Vladimir Putin appeared in public after a 10-day absence, meeting with Kyrgyz President Almazbek Atambayev in St. Petersburg. His unexplained absence fueled speculation about his health, power, and love life, but he dismissed rumors, saying it would be "boring without gossip."

Scientists suggest that Jupiter's massive migration may have destroyed "super-Earths" in the inner solar system, clearing the way for the formation of Earth and other smaller planets. Jupiter's inward-outward journey sent planetesimals crashing into the sun, shaping the solar system's current configuration.

Two US Army National Guard members, Hasan Edmonds (22) and Jonas "Yunus" Edmonds (29), were arrested in Illinois for allegedly conspiring to provide material support to ISIS. They planned to attack a US military facility in northern Illinois. Both face up to 15 years in prison.

Jeremy Clarkson, host of Top Gear, sparked controversy in Argentina by driving a Porsche with a registration plate referencing the 1982 Falklands War. The incident led to an angry mob attacking the crew, and Clarkson was later suspended by the BBC for allegedly hitting a producer.

A new biography, "Becoming Steve Jobs," presents a kinder, gentler portrait of Steve Jobs, humanizing him through interviews with those who knew him in his later career. Apple has endorsed the book, contradicting Walter Isaacson's biography, which portrayed Jobs as cruel and egotistical.

Actress Taraji P. Henson apologized for claiming her son was racially profiled during a traffic stop in Glendale, CA. Dash cam video contradicted her son's claims, showing he was pulled over for marijuana possession, not racial profiling. Henson retracted her accusations and apologized to the police department.

Experts addressed six viewer questions about Germanwings Flight 9525. The rate of descent was slow due to the co-pilot's deliberate actions, not a malfunction. There's no technology to prevent planes from landing elsewhere, and live cameras aren't feasible. The plane's fuel and lack of explosion suggest no external interference.

Gareth Bale scored twice for Wales, beating Israel 3-0 in Euro 2016 qualification. This win puts Wales at the top of their group, their first major finals since 1958. Bale dominated the game, despite criticism from the Spanish press for prioritizing country over club.

African safaris on horseback offer a unique experience, allowing tourists to get closer to wildlife without disturbing them. Wait A Little horse safaris in South Africa's game reserves train ex-racehorses to navigate the bush, providing a safe and thrilling experience for guests.

Nigeria's military has retaken the town of Gwoza from Boko Haram, which declared it its "caliphate" in 2014. The victory comes ahead of the country's general elections, which have been postponed due to security concerns. The military has recovered arms and ammunition, and a massive cordon is being conducted.

Protesters in Nigeria's Rivers state have fired gunshots and torched an electoral office, threatening a peaceful national election. The opposition party claims the vote has been rigged, while the ruling party denies the allegations. Violence could spread if the opposition loses.

Italy's high court overturned the guilty verdicts of Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito in the 2007 murder of Meredith Kercher. The decision is final, and Knox and Sollecito are now free. The Kercher family is disappointed, and they may appeal to the European Court of Human Rights.

Tropical Cyclone Pam devastated Vanuatu, causing widespread destruction and flooding in the capital, Port Vila. Over 90% of houses were destroyed, and 65 islands were affected. 11 people have been confirmed dead, with the toll expected to rise. Thousands are homeless and in need of aid.

A bipartisan summit on criminal justice reform is taking place in Washington, featuring prominent figures from both parties, including Attorney General Eric Holder and former President Barack Obama. The event aims to address the issue of mass incarceration and promote "liberty and justice for all."

Zayn Malik is leaving One Direction after five years. The band announced the news on Facebook and Twitter, stating they will continue as a four-piece. Fans responded with emotional tributes, and music streams increased by 330% globally, with 769% in the US.

Zayn Malik spoke publicly for the first time since leaving One Direction, apologizing for the pain he's caused fans. He cited feeling uncomfortable and unhappy with the group's dynamics, but feels more in control and doing what's right for himself and the remaining members.

The trailer for "SPECTRE" reveals Daniel Craig's James Bond on a new mission. The film picks up after "Skyfall" and follows Bond as he tries to infiltrate the global terrorist organization SPECTRE. The trailer teases a closely guarded plot with cryptic clues and mysterious characters.

Russian President Vladimir Putin's sudden disappearance sparked widespread speculation, with many believing he was ill or dead. The Kremlin denied rumors, releasing old photos and claiming Putin was "absolutely healthy." The incident highlights Putin's grip on power and the potential consequences of his sudden departure.

Charlottesville Police found no evidence to support a University of Virginia student's claim of being raped at a Phi Kappa Psi house, contradicting a Rolling Stone article published last year. Police Chief Tim Longo said the investigation didn't rule out the possibility of an assault occurring.

Kylie Minogue will perform a 90-minute show at Dubai's 20th Dubai World Cup on March 28. The event features $30 million in prize money and luxury brands Longines and Jaguar sponsoring two races. Minogue is excited to bring her show to the Dubai World Cup, a major part of her annual calendar.

Thousands of Tunisians marched in the capital to protest terrorism, following a deadly attack on the Bardo Museum two weeks ago. The protesters, including former foreign minister Rafik Abdessalem, chanted "Tunisia is free, and out with terrorism" and held banners saying "We are not afraid."

Cabinet-maker Michael Ibsen has crafted a coffin for Richard III, one of his distant relatives, who died over 500 years ago. The discovery of Richard III's remains in 2012 was a vindication of the "Looking for Richard" project, which aimed to reevaluate the King's reputation.

Sen. Harry Reid's announcement not seeking re-election creates a power vacuum for Senate Democrats. Chuck Schumer, with over $13.4 million in campaign funds, is poised to succeed Reid. Schumer's 20-year track record, media savvy, and personal political skill make him a strong candidate for leadership.

A late-night shooting in Panama City Beach, Florida, injured 7 college-age people, including students from Alabama A&M University. Authorities arrested 22-year-old David Jarmichael Daniels on 7 counts of attempted murder. The shooting occurred at a residence on Thomas Drive, with 3 in critical condition.

A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps on Tuesday, killing all 150 people on board. The plane took off from Barcelona, Spain, and was headed to Dusseldorf, Germany. The cause of the crash is unknown, but officials are investigating.

AMC's "The Walking Dead" companion series, now titled "Fear The Walking Dead," has been officially announced. The prequel series, set in Los Angeles at the onset of the zombie outbreak, will premiere in late summer and stars Cliff Curtis, Kim Dickens, and Alycia Debnam Carey.

The article discusses the NCAA men's basketball tournament, specifically the Elite Eight games. Kentucky's undefeated Wildcats dominated West Virginia 78-39, advancing to the Final Four. Notre Dame and Wisconsin also won, while Arizona edged Xavier 68-60. The article highlights the impressive performances of various players, including Trey Lyles and Demetrius Jackson.

Lewis Hamilton secured pole position for the Malaysian Grand Prix, dominating qualifying in torrential conditions. He edged out Sebastian Vettel, who took second place after Nico Rosberg was blocked on a lap. Hamilton's teammate Rosberg finished third, while Toro Rosso's Max Verstappen started sixth in his second race.

Yemen's President Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi joined Egyptian leaders at the Arab League summit as airstrikes raged on in Sanaa. The Saudi-led operation, al-Hazm Storm, has killed dozens of civilians, with Human Rights Watch reporting up to 34 deaths. The US supports the operation logistically.

A commuter train collided with a car near the University of Southern California campus in Los Angeles, causing 21 people to be injured. The train derailed after the car got wedged between a pole and the train. 10 were hospitalized, with one in critical and one in grave condition.

Germanwings Flight 9525, an Airbus A320, crashed into the Alps on March 24, 2015, killing all 150 people on board. Co-pilot Andreas Lubitz, 28, manipulated the flight controls while the pilot was in the restroom, causing a steady descent at 3,000-3,500 feet per minute.

A petition with nearly 1 million signatures, calling for Jeremy Clarkson's reinstatement to "Top Gear," was delivered to the BBC's London headquarters, accompanied by an armored tank. Clarkson was suspended after allegedly hitting a producer, and the show was not broadcast as scheduled.

The author shares their experience of coping with the loss of 16 students and 2 teachers in a plane crash 19 years ago. They offer condolences to the community of Haltern am See, Germany, who lost 16 students and 2 teachers in a similar crash, and acknowledge the long and painful journey ahead.

The article discusses the shocking case of Germanwings Flight 9525, where first officer Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed the plane, killing all 150 people on board. It highlights the incompatibility between the public's perception of pilots as highly trained and professional, and the reality that pilots can be just like ordinary people with flaws and vulnerabilities.

The article is about a March 30, 2015, episode of CNN Student News. The episode covered three main topics: 

1. The 2015 Nigerian general election, where voters in Africa's largest democracy went to the polls.
2. An astronaut on a 340-day mission to the International Space Station, who will be part of experiments conducted during their stay.
3. A fire-extinguishing invention using low-frequency sound waves.

The article also invites students to request to be featured on the CNN Student News Roll Call by commenting on the page with their school name, mascot, city, and state.

Manchester United beat Tottenham 3-0, boosting their chances of Champions League qualification. Wayne Rooney scored his third goal, and the win left United two points behind second-placed Manchester City. Tottenham is now seventh, six points behind the top four. Chelsea lost 1-1 to Southampton, while Everton won 3-0 over Newcastle.

Thousands of Singaporeans gathered to bid farewell to Lee Kuan Yew, the city-state's founding prime minister, in pouring rain. The funeral service was attended by foreign dignitaries, including Bill Clinton and Narendra Modi, and featured a 21-gun salute and minute of silence.

Rebels seized Yemen's Taiz airport, killing one civilian and wounding 82 others. The UN warned the country is at "the edge of civil war." The Houthis, who have taken over the city, are backed by the UN, but calls for calm have done little to quell violence.

A University of Oklahoma Sigma Alpha Epsilon house mother, Beauton Gilbow, released a video singing the N-word, sparking controversy. However, two black alumni defended her, saying she's not racist and was caught up in the moment. The fraternity chapter was suspended and eventually closed.

A 475-pound leatherback sea turtle, named Yawkey, was rescued in South Carolina after washing up on a beach. It's believed to be a juvenile, less than 10 years old, and is receiving treatment at the South Carolina Aquarium. Release plans are underway, likely within the next few days.

ISIS claimed responsibility for the deadly attack at Tunisia's Bardo Museum, killing 23 people, including 12 foreigners. The attackers used automatic weapons and hand grenades, and authorities arrested nine suspects, including four linked to the bloodshed. The attack has raised concerns about terrorism in Tunisia.

Nuclear talks between world powers and Iran intensified, but key sticking points remained unresolved ahead of a Tuesday deadline. Iran wants sanctions lifted immediately, while the US wants a phased approach. The two countries disagree on limits on advanced nuclear technology and research.

A California federal jury ordered Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams to pay $4 million in copyright damages for allegedly stealing Marvin Gaye's 1977 hit "Got to Give It Up" in their 2013 song "Blurred Lines." The verdict was reached after 8 days of trial testimony.

Over 54% of the world's population now lives in cities, with 66% predicted by 2050. Africa's urban hubs are booming, with North African cities dominating the top 5 in a report by PwC. Cities like Cairo, Tunis, and Johannesburg are driving economic growth, while sub-Saharan cities excel in diversity and population growth.

Comedian Trevor Noah will replace Jon Stewart as host of "The Daily Show" after 16 years. Noah, 31, debuted on the show in December and has made three appearances. Stewart approves of his replacement, and the show has a history of launching successful contributors.

In Lagos, Nigeria, "free readers" gather around newspaper vendors to discuss current events. Despite the name, they pay a small fee, with prices varying depending on the vendor. This unique business model has led to new friendships and even job offers, despite a decline in newspaper readers due to internet usage.

India's Supreme Court has struck down Section 66A of the 2008 Information Technology Act, a law that allowed authorities to arrest and jail people for comments on social media. The court deemed the law "unconstitutional" and "vague," protecting freedom of expression and democracy.

Three educators in Southern California were arrested and charged with operating a "pay-to-stay" scheme, collecting $6 million in tuition from foreign students on student visas. The scheme allegedly allowed students to live in other states, compromising national security and cheating foreign nationals.

The Duchess of Cambridge, Kate Middleton, made her last official appearance in London, visiting the Stephen Lawrence Centre and a church hosting a youth charity. She is due to give birth in mid- to late April, marking the second child for her and Prince William.

The article discusses the Germanwings Flight 9525 crash, where co-pilot Andreas Lubitz intentionally crashed the plane into the French Alps, killing all 150 people on board. The author, a psychologist, highlights the importance of psychological testing for pilots and the unpredictability of human factors in aviation accidents.

Sam Taylor-Johnson, director of "Fifty Shades of Grey," won't return for the sequel "Fifty Shades Darker." She expressed gratitude for her experience but wishes the new director success. Author E.L. James had control over the screenplay, which was written by Kelly Marcel for the first film.

Arnold Palmer, 85, vows to participate in the Masters' ceremonial opening tee shot despite a dislocated shoulder. He tripped on a carpet at the Father-Son Challenge in December, but plans to join Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player on the course on April 9, despite not being allowed to swing a club.

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani says a nuclear deal with international powers is within reach, citing recent common ground. US Secretary of State John Kerry says "substantial progress" has been made, but "important gaps remain." A framework pact is expected by March 31, with sanctions relief a key issue.

In China, 61 million "left-behind children" struggle due to absent parents, often working in cities. These children face behavioral problems, mental health issues, and limited access to education and healthcare. The hukou system, which restricts migrants' access to urban services, exacerbates the issue.

Afghan President Ashraf Ghani's visit to Washington amid potential Taliban peace talks highlights the challenges of negotiations. The US should support talks by promoting conditions for success, such as a vulnerable Taliban and a stable Afghan government. The US can aid by slowing troop withdrawals and boosting the government's legitimacy.

Iraqi forces, backed by Shia militias, have captured key areas in Tikrit, a city held by ISIS since June. The forces raised the Iraqi flag over the governorate and hospital buildings, killing at least 26 militants. The city has been the target of a renewed push since March.

Based on Hillary Clinton's history, we can expect her to use the "Clinton scandal playbook" to address the controversy. This involves: 1) attacking the accuser and investigative process, 2) sticking it out and waiting for the news cycle to shift, and 3) rallying the party base to fight back against opponents.

Swedish prosecutors have asked Julian Assange to be interviewed in London and have his DNA taken via a swab. Assange has been in the Ecuadorian Embassy since 2012 to avoid extradition. His defense lawyer says this is a step they've been requesting for four years.

New Zealand secured a thrilling semifinal victory over South Africa, reaching the World Cup final for the first time. Grant Elliott hit a six off the penultimate ball to seal the win, as New Zealand chased a target of 298 in 43 overs.

In China, a growing number of young people, like 25-year-old Robert Zhao, are rediscovering Buddhism, drawn to its spiritual practices and culture. Many combine Buddhist beliefs with modern life, but some, like Zhao, consider becoming monks, seeking a spiritual anchor in a competitive society.

An explosive-laden truck exploded at a camp for Egyptian security forces in Al-Arish, North Sinai, killing a civilian and injuring 44 people, including 42 soldiers and 2 civilians. The driver was also killed. No one has claimed responsibility for the attack, which is part of a recent surge in violence.

Islamic militants Al-Shabaab attacked government offices in Baidoa, Somalia, killing 9 people, including 4 attackers. The attack targeted the regional president's house and Ethiopian soldiers. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility and has shifted focus to terrorist attacks globally, including in the US, with US authorities downplaying the threat.

Tennis player Eugenie Bouchard teamed up with Justin Bieber for a game of doubles at the Annual Desert Smash event. Bouchard previously mentioned Bieber as her ideal date, but he hasn't responded to her tweet. Bieber's charity match was for Cancer for College, a scholarship organization.

A potential Iran nuclear deal may not prompt Israel to attack, as its military capability is already in place. A strike would likely degrade Iran's program but not eliminate it, and would lead to international condemnation, sanctions collapse, and strained relations with Arab regimes.

Kenya is the third-largest exporter of cut flowers, accounting for 35% of EU sales. The country's sunny climate and transport links enable year-round flower production, with over 500,000 people dependent on the trade. Kenya is exploring new markets, including Australia and Japan, to diversify its exports.

Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson hosted "Saturday Night Live" and starred in memorable sketches, including a "Bambi" remake and a WWE promo. He then made a surprise appearance at Wrestlemania 31, teaming up with UFC champion Ronda Rousey to take on WWE executives Stephanie McMahon and Triple H.

Approximately 150 homeless people were given a special tour of Vatican City, led by Archbishop Konrad Krajewski. The tour included visits to the Vatican Museums, Sistine Chapel, and other areas, offering a unique opportunity for the homeless to experience the Vatican's artistic patrimony.

The UK Supreme Court ruled that previously secret correspondence between Prince Charles and government officials must be made public. The Guardian newspaper had been fighting for the release since 2005, citing concerns about the prince's potential influence on politics.

The article explores how human pressure has changed Rudyard Kipling's "Law of the Jungle," which prohibits beasts from eating humans. In India, tiger-human conflict is a major threat, with most attacks occurring when people are mistaken for prey. Conservation efforts are paying off, with a 30% increase in tiger population.

Indiana Gov. Michael Pence initially defended the state's Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) despite concerns it could allow businesses to discriminate against LGBT individuals. However, he later expressed a willingness to "fix" the law, with possible solutions including adopting state-wide nondiscrimination laws or amending the RFRA to exempt local ordinances.

Jordan Spieth won the Valspar Championship in a three-way playoff, becoming the fourth player since 1940 to win twice on the PGA Tour before turning 22. He's now focused on beating Rory McIlroy for the world No.1 spot, citing the victory as a confidence booster heading into majors.

The article is about a CNN Student News program that aired on April 1, 2015. The program covered various topics, including a trip around the world, wages in the US, and the potential use of cyborg cockroaches as rescuers. The program is designed for students aged 13 and older, and viewers can request to be featured on the show by commenting on the page.

Lewis Hamilton won the Australian Grand Prix, his 34th career victory, to lead a Mercedes one-two. Sebastian Vettel finished third for Ferrari. Hamilton controlled the race, with teammate Nico Rosberg in second. The win marked Mercedes' continued dominance and Hamilton's first win in Melbourne since 2008.

Actor Michael Douglas wrote about a recent incident where his 14-year-old son Dylan was targeted by anti-Semitism in an unidentified country in southern Europe. Douglas, a UN messenger of peace, urges individuals and society to combat anti-Semitism, citing its rise due to income inequality and extremism.

Researchers discovered a 1,000-year-old Anglo-Saxon potion for eye infections that may hold the key to wiping out the superbug MRSA. The "eyesalve" remedy, found in a medieval textbook, was tested on MRSA cultures and found to be incredibly potent, killing up to 90% of bacteria.

After his election, Benjamin Netanyahu rolled back his pre-election comments on a Palestinian state, but the damage may have been done to relations with the US and Palestinians. The US may reassess its relationship with Israel, and the Palestinians may try again for UN recognition.

Indiana's new "religious freedom" law allows businesses to turn away gay and lesbian customers if it conflicts with their religious beliefs. The law has sparked a heated debate, with supporters claiming it protects their rights and opponents labeling it as bigotry.

London's Fourth Plinth art project unveiled "Gift Horse," a 13-foot bronze skeleton with a ribbon-shaped electronic ticker tied to its leg, exploring power, money, and history. Created by Hans Haacke, it comments on the relationship between art and commerce, sparking debate and mixed reactions from tourists and locals.

Adam West and Burt Ward, the original Batman and Robin, hinted at a new animated 90-minute feature for the 50th anniversary of the 1960s Batman TV series in 2016. The project's details are unclear, with Ward seeming uncertain about discussing it further.

US officials extended talks on a framework agreement with Iran on its nuclear program to Wednesday, citing progress but remaining issues. Diplomats worked late to resolve differences, with a focus on sanctions relief, nuclear technology advancement, and potential sanctions re-imposition. A deal is seen as crucial for Iran's economy.

BBC Director-General Tony Hall received death threats after Jeremy Clarkson was dropped from "Top Gear." The threats were made via email from outside the UK, following an altercation between Clarkson and producer Oisin Tymon. The BBC is investigating and looking into a new host for the show.

Julianne Moore's Oscar win for "Still Alice" shines a light on Alzheimer's disease, which affects 5 million Americans and is expected to reach 13.5 million by 2050. The author, a child of Alzheimer's, launches the Wipe Out Alzheimer's Challenge to educate, engage, and empower women to fight the disease.

A 35-year-old Canadian tourist, Jennifer Karren, was killed after a small inflatable tour boat collided with a whale off Mexico's coast. Two others were injured, and Karren was pronounced dead at a hospital despite receiving first aid and CPR. The incident is under investigation.

Simone Gbagbo, former Ivory Coast first lady, was sentenced to 20 years in prison for crimes against humanity following post-election violence in 2010 that killed over 3,000 people. Her husband, Laurent Gbagbo, is awaiting trial at the Hague International Criminal Court on similar charges.

Rory McIlroy was reunited with the 3-iron club he threw into the lake at Doral during the WGC-Cadillac Championship, thanks to Donald Trump. McIlroy played the club again, resulting in a double bogey, and finished tied for 9th. Trump plans to auction or display the club.
references:
Zully Broussard decided to give a kidney to a stranger .
A new computer program helped her donation spur transplants for six kidney patients .

The 20th MLS season begins this weekend .
League has changed dramatically since its inception in 1996 .
Some question whether rules regarding salary caps and transfers need to change .
